bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 9, 1875

div1.p: Reed assures Emilie Lawrence of his devotion, and he apologizes for the ironic tone which offended her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 9, 1875
div1.p:
I had al-
ready begun a letter, this morning,
and had written to the bottom of
the fifth page, but upon the ar-
rival of your letter, dated Dec.
6th, I concluded to toss that one
aside and begin anew. Not that
I had written anything that I
would not have you read, (for
it was as affectionate as I
could well make it) but simply
because I am of opinion that I can
write one more appropriate,
under the present circumstan-
ces. I scarcely know how to
commence it, however, since so
many conflicting ideas flood my mind
that I hardly feel myself able to reduce them to
an intelligent narrative. When, 3 weeks ago, or more,
you wrote that you had received a letter from one,
whose name I will not mention, and that you felt it
your duty to reply, lest his sensibilities should be
aggrieved, you little thought, my darling E. that you
were writing words that would sink deeply into
my heart, and that those words they would be misconstrued to
the extent which you say they have been. And
I, in answering your letter, certainly did not sup-
pose that I was inflicting “more wounds thatn
you once thought you would ever submit to from
any gentleman.” That sentence, my darling, I
have read, over & over again, and, believe me when
I tell you that the knowledge of the fact that I
have so “wounded” you has caused me the deep-
est pain & contrition of heart; albeit you sup-
posed that it would be a “gratification” to me to be
made cognizant of the fact. This, of course, my darling
Emilie, was not intended to be “cutting.” Did You believe
what you said; that it would be a “gratification” to
me? You also add; “I do not see how after
relating to you how much your letter could
had grieved me, you could repeat your re-
proaches, even with redoubled energy”! This
sentence, also, bears upon its face the evidence
that you felt and meant what you wrote.
And yet, my darling, you will pardon me, if I beg
leave to differ with you, and however reluct-
antly I may do so. “I derive no pleasure from
the censure that you are continually heaping
upon me.” Of course, my darling, you are aware
of the force of that sentence. “I am not ac-
customed to harsh words”:- the inference being
that I am accustomed to use them towards you.
“I cannot take your reproofs, when I am
innocent.” “Surely, if my home is not with
you, you need not concern yourself how
far I go from home.” Were none of these
words, my darling, meant to be “cutting”? Read
them over again, & see if you need ask, “where
is my Independence”? If you have none
with you, at present, my darling, it is because
you enclosed it all in your letter of the 6th,
or else my knowledge of the definition of the
word is very deficient. Indeed, although my
letter was written in a plain style, I did
not intend, my darling little Sweet-heart, to
wound you at all. I attempted, as briefly &
correctly as I could, to give you an expression
of my opinion of the subject then under dis-
cussion. A subject which, looking at in the light
that I then did, seemed to be of some im-
portance, but which, to you, seemed “trivial”.
Had I not loved you dearly, I should have
never noticed the matter, & had I entertained
the remotest idea of breaking our engage-
ment, I would have quietly permitted you to
have com written to the unknown gentleman,
& upon your acknowledgement of the same, asked
for a release. I little imagined that what I had
intended as an expression of my affection would
be construed into “words of reproach.” “con-
tinual reproach”. But so it has been inter-
preted, and upon my head I take all the
blame. Would to God that the last month
of my life could be blotted from memory!
Oh! my darling, my precious Emilie, if I could
really bring myself to the belief, that you
really intended to say that I am “heaping cen-
sure upon you continually,” this letter
would bear to you the request to release me
from all claims, for Heaven knows, if thus you
think, I could never be brave enough to look
you in the countenance! Oh! my God! how
little understood is my heart! and will I not
go down to my last resting-spot still
misunderstood? Were I but convinced that
you believed that I had intentionally censured
you & that continually, I should be the
most miserable man that ever breathed!
As God is my Maker, & as I expect to be
judged, at the last Day, for my words, I
declare that it was not my intention to
grieve you, my darling, & that what I wrote
concerning your living in Baltimore & the suc-
ceeding sentences, was meant as the merest
fun! You, my darling, have written
much in Irony, & have been much surprised
whenever I misunderstood your words.
Yet when I made use of it, this time, I did
not think that you would seize upon
it as the weapon with which to deal
your blows! “You need not concern your-
self how far I go from home”! Oh! Yes!
my darling, I should always feel an in-
terest in you and your whereabouts. I don't
love one moment & forget the next-and I had
hoped that you would not object to my fol-
lowing your course with a friendly eye, un-
til you gave me unmistakably to under-
stand that I “need not concern myself.”
You have often expressed yourself as
wonderinged whether “the Future will be simelar”?
I am sorry to see this, my darling, for you
thereby strongly express a doubt in my
future love and kindness. 'Tis strange
that I have had no doubts on this point,
simply because, I know that I could live
happily with one who would return my
love. I would not mislead you on this
point, my darling Emilie. You must satisfy
yourself that I will love & protect you, be-
fore you give yourself into my hands.
I want no compulsion, my darling. Your
act must be as free as the breath you draw!
Although, my only happiness in life is your
love, yet I had rather go through life
alone and unknown than to marry a lady
who had no confidence in my love. Oh! how
it grieves me when I think that I have
given your cause to doubt me already!
Well, Emilie darling, all that I can do is to
beg that you will forgive me and to try and
to forget the Past. Send back the letters
which you would have me recall, that I may
destroy them. I think our recent lesson should
teach us to beware of writing what we
do not mean- I promise faithfully to avoid
everything that can possibly lead to any
misunderstanding- I acknowledge that I am
too quick in forming my opinions, and will
endeavor to restrain myself in this re-
spect. I will confide in you wholly,
& under no circumstances will I
distrust you. May I hope that the same
will be accorded me? Oh! on my knee
to-night, I will pray that I may be forgiven
for the wrong that I have done you- and
that you may forget it- And as your lay
your pure, sweet cheek upon your
pillow, tonight, know that there is one
who loves you more dearly than all
else in this world!

and believe me, as ever, your fond
